contentBlocks.data: This topic teaches how to perform a linear search in a Python list. Linear search is a basic algorithm that checks each element in a list sequentially to determine if a target value exists. The learner will write code that iterates through a list, compares each element to the target, and prints the index of the first occurrence if found, or a specific value if the target element is not present in the list.

data: The program reads two lines of input: the first line contains space-separated integers representing the list, and the second line contains the integer target value to search for.
The program iterates through the list, comparing each element to the target value.
If the target value is found, the program prints the index of its first occurrence and stops searching.
If the target value is not present in the list, the program prints -1 to indicate that the target element is not present in the list.

contentBlocks.data:
Read a line of input and split it into a list of integers
Read the next line of input as the target integer
For each index and value in the list:
    If the value equals the target:
        Print the index
        Stop the search
If the loop completes without finding the target:
    Print -1

data: The input list contains no elements, so the program prints -1 to indicate that the target element is not present in the list.
The target value appears multiple times in the list, so the program prints the index of its first occurrence.
The target value is the first element in the list, so the program prints 0.
The target value is the last element in the list, so the program prints the index corresponding to the last position.
The input list may contain zero or more integers.
The target value is a single integer.
The program must print only the index of the first occurrence of the target value, or -1 if the target element is not present in the list.
All output must be produced using the print() function.

data.time: O(n), where n is the number of elements in the list, because each element may need to be checked once.
data.space: O(1), excluding the space required to store the input list, since only a constant amount of additional memory is used.

sampleTestCases.explanation: The list is [3, 8, 2, 7, 5] and the target value is 7. The target value 7 is found at index 3, so the program prints 3.
The input list is empty and the target value is 4. Since the list contains no elements, the program prints -1 to indicate that the target element is not present in the list.
